Flood Sensing

Overview

This project develops DIY flood alert and water level monitoring systems, initially prototyped for use in New Orleans, Louisiana. The goal is to create affordable, community-deployable sensors that can detect rising water levels and provide early warning.

The Technology

The system uses:

  • Ultrasonic distance sensors (HC-SR04 or RCWL-1601) to measure water levels
  • LoRa radio modules for long-range, low-power wireless communication
  • Microcontrollers (Adafruit ItsyBitsy M4 or Feather boards)
  • Gateway nodes that relay data to the internet via WiFi

How It Works

Sensor nodes are mounted above areas prone to flooding. The ultrasonic sensor measures the distance to the water surface. As water levels rise, the distance decreases, triggering alerts when thresholds are crossed.

Data is transmitted via LoRa radio to gateway nodes, which post readings to online databases (like FarmOS) for monitoring and visualization.

Design Considerations

  • Low power operation using timer circuits for solar-powered deployments
  • Weatherproof enclosures using PVC pipe and sealed fittings
  • Multiple sensing options including time-of-flight LIDAR sensors for greater accuracy

Applications

  • Street flooding detection
  • Storm drain monitoring
  • Creek and river level monitoring
  • Basement flooding alerts

To find out more, visit: Edge Collective - Flood Sensing
